section.title: Migrating from Agavi 0.10 to 0.11
section.para: Migrating from Agavi 0.10 is unfortunately quite a lot of work because of the more-or-less complete overhaul of the framework.

The easiest way to get started is to create a completely new project with the agavi script and start moving modules and actions one by one, copying the execute method from the old action to the new one, testing if it works and fix whatever breaks.
A few pointers to help on the way:

listitem.para: Parameters set with $this->setAttribute('foo', 'bar') in the action's execute-method are now directly available in the template. You no longer need to manually set the template attributes in the view.
Read up on the new templating system (http://groups.google.com/group/agavi-users/browse_thread/thread/6e1a1033b4b8b77c)

Routing, the request object, the controller, user, translation manager and the request data are now available directly in the templates via $ro, $rq, $ct, $us, $tm and $rd , no need to pass these objects to the view. The name of the variables is configurabe through output_types.xml

Action::getRequestMethod() is deprecated. Actions now have executeRead() and executeWrite() that handle HTTP GET and HTTP POST respectively. If you really need, you can also use a plain execute() which would handle both GET and POST.

$this->getContext()->getRequest()->getParameter() is no longer needed. The action's execute -method takes an AgaviRequestDataHolder -object as it's parameter and the request parameters are available via that object's getParameter-method.
Actions no longer return attributes of the View-class (return View::SUCCESS), but strings. For an action that wants to indicate it was successful, you would return the string "Success".

Views do not need to set the template file manually anymore. The view makes an educated guess as to the filename (<Name><ReturnValueFromAction>.php). For example, if IndexAction returns 'Success', IndexSuccessView would use the template IndexSuccess.php.
Application config variables are now available via AgaviConfig::get(). For instance, the modpub -directory would be AgaviConfig::get('core.modpub'). No need for constants anymore (AG_MOD_PUB)

Views now have multiple execute-methods (eg executeHtml, executeRss, executeXml etc), agavi chooses which one to run based on the output type. This means one view can handle HTML, RSS, XML and, say, PDF output at once, and will choose the proper template based on the configuration in output_types.xml. All you need to do is add a new execute-method to the view (and of course configure the output type in output_types.xml).

para.emphasis: !!!! DO NOT USE THE PLAIN FALLBACK execute() METHOD IN THE VIEWS !!!!

listitem.para: This is simply because if you set the output type to, say, RSS but the view does not support it, you don't really want to display a HTML page or whatever, you probably want to throw an exception or something similar.

para.emphasis: !!!! ALWAYS ALWAYS ALWAYS USE THE OUTPUT-TYPE BASED EXECUTE METHODS !!!!
